conclusion: Understanding the setup with two baffles, electric field, and magnetic field.
Particle with mass m and charge q is launched horizontally with velocity v₀.
Particle enters magnetic field at P and exits between Q and N without colliding with baffles.
Angle between particle's velocity direction when entering magnetic field and PQ is 60 degrees.
Neglect gravity in the problem.
Visualizing the particle's motion through electric and magnetic fields.
Particle experiences downward force qE in electric field.
Particle has constant horizontal velocity v₀ and downward acceleration due to electric field.
Velocity at P has both horizontal component v₀ and vertical component due to electric field.
Horizontal distance from launch position to P is x, vertical distance is y.
Time to reach P is t = x / v₀.
Downward velocity component at P is v_y = (qE / m) * (x / v₀).
Angle θ between velocity at P and PQ is 60 degrees, tan(θ) = v_y / v₀.
Solve for x: x = √3 * (m v₀²) / (qE).
Distance s from emission position to P is the straight-line distance.
Particle's path is a parabola due to constant acceleration downward and constant horizontal velocity.
Image 1 shows initial setup with electric field E and magnetic field region.
Image 2 labels x as horizontal movement distance.
Image 3 labels y as vertical movement distance.
Image 4 labels vx as horizontal movement velocity and vy as vertical movement velocity.
Image 5 labels s as distance from emission position to point P.
